One thing I think may help with dPoW..and this is off the top of my head, so error prone but the flow of dPoW summarized I think would be good..For a 3rd party chain for example : Block Mined -> Blockhash sent to nodes -> Consensus reached -> Notaries Broadcast to BTC network ->  TX in BTC mempool -> Notaries broadcast to nodes -> once confirmed,  blocks are locked to prevent reorg  (something like that) ..Im going to take a stab at summarizing but the more thoughts on it the better

Author: Daiyox#2701
Content: @PTYX A random thought on sales relating to dPoW..I don't know how often or not it's thrown out, but it seems like taking down defenses / assumptions fast would be good..Letting people know they could always implement a notary system of their own, ultimately implement dPoW 100% maintained by their own project would be a great angle, but for now why not give it a try on existing infrastructure..I'd think chances are they'd end up just sticking with the KMD backed notaries..In short, I think removing all the tribalism defenses is good, tell them they can own it all if they want

Author: jl777c#5810
Content:
found more articles for the "marketing is all that matters" peoples:
https://cointelegraph.com/news/ex-bittorrent-exec-says-theres-no-way-tron-will-manage-bittorrents-token

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: unsubstantiated, but if you have a lot of OMG, maybe a bit concerning: https://www.reddit.com/r/Buttcoin/comments/aexbya/ceo_of_omisego_not_seen_in_months_and_4_people/

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: when the tech isnt complete and there isnt a mass market solution yet, then yes, it can be argued that marketing makes the diffference between all the projects which dont have working tech

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but like the one eyed man in the land of the blind...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the first with actual scalable crypto tech that can be made easy to use, well, it seems even without out of this world marketing, it will do quite well

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all along. KMD plan is to create the working tech. then if our marketing is somehow not good enough, we will work to improve that. however, based on what I see, our marketing is indeed improved and what more can you ask for than continuous improvement

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://www.coindesk.com/0-success-why-blockchain-apps-just-arent-taking-off

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: continuous improvement in all areas, that is what I have been advocating and personally doing that on the coding side. barterDEX was a good example. while others were just marketing the DEX they didnt have, we made it and it allowed non-technical people (who were patient) to actually do atomic swaps. That was quite an improvement from the cli based "solutions" that were hyped, or the onchain   "DEX" (what else can a token swap be??), but we did notice that it wasnt easy enough

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so we started the mm2 project to redo the marketmaker from scratch with the new design requirements that were not part of mm1. With this iteration, will it be enough to get mass market? Not sure, but we will find out what is missing and then be able to do mm3 if needed

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is how you get to a working mass market solution. release, get feedback, iterate

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i also hear a lot of "where is the roadmap" which is probably more from a desire to buy the rumor and sell the news and wanting some specific dates.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: News flash!

Author: passcombo.com üè¥‚ò†üçã#0622
Content: I've seen some info new hyperdex/mm2.0 is built but didn't see explanation what is actually being improved/why it's done

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: tech innovation does not work on a strict calendar, we can make general estimates, but usually issues are found along the way that take more time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: barterDEX is so old tech, it was designed to work with coins that dont have CLTV implemented. Back when it was started only a few coins had that. nowadays, virtually all coins do

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: SPV support was added AFTER the initial barterDEX was already working

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as was ETH support

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so when you add totally new features after something is done, well, it ends up like adding stuff to something after it is already done and the end result isnt optimally streamlined

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it also made assumptions about utxo availability locally for broadcasting to ordermatch

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it does work and even under load as we saw over 100,000 atomic swaps completed, but if you were not technical enough it was hard to understand what went wrong if something wasnt right

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this last part is the big question, if we can make it so non-technical users are able to understand how to use it well enough.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: many users have nodes behind NAT and couldnt do direct connect, which an atomic swap requires

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: to solve that mm1 used a third node to act as a conduit

Author: passcombo.com üè¥‚ò†üçã#0622
Content: ok so redesign needed to be up to date with current tech and optimization included... the pace in crypto is quite fast

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: mm2 uses bittorrent so all nodes can direct connect to each other

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well supporting atomic swaps for coins without CLTV, this was quite ambitious and nobody else even tried to do that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: also there were no cupholders

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: think of it as a manual transmission car. To a person who can only drive automatic transmission, it is not very good car. To someone that can drive manual, it is just fine

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe a better analogy is model T car as compared to horse and buggy
